Headline: 69 followers
Comment:
Valid point!

While mental and physical well-being should be important, and youth should prioritize it, you will always find that the youths who look for this are from financially stable backgrounds with parents to fall back to! The other half of youths who had to work harder to reach this point, with modest to low-income backgrounds, and with family responsibilities have to have a continuous flow of income and cannot afford to find and choose working conditions on one‚Äôs own choices. To attain the ‚Äúwealthiness‚Äù you mention, some youths generally reach the freedom after 30s which is not wrong but just fact.

Most MNCs have sales persons in foreign countries who pitch and sell Indian workforce as cheap labours who can work more hours. This needs to change otherwise the wellness mentality will never set in.

Headline: Facilitating organisational & individual growth. Going about it gently.
Comment: Agreed. People like me set the tone 20+ years ago by buying into the glamour of the long hours and the hustle, often adapting beliefs of others ahead of us / other geographies. We might find it harder to see what the 20 somethings are doing as actually needing courage, but that distance is for us to cover. I wouldn't have had the space to say I am prioritising my well-being in my 20s. When I now see gym bags at work / bicycles at the parking lot / conversations on training runs, I applaud their efforts to make good health into a habit.

Headline: Happy Culture Builder | Bestselling Author | Leadership Coach | AI Nerd | Agile Devotee | Operational Efficiency through Gamification | Two Decades of Experience
Comment:
Great point here, love how you've highlighted the value of health over material success. It's true‚Äîunhealthy habits sneak up on you over time. Many workplaces preach work-life balance, but then they load up on back-to-back meetings and unrealistic deadlines. If a company really wants its people to thrive, it's gotta make room for personal growth, time off, and, well, just living.¬†

Having systems in place for employees to prioritize health isn't just a nice-to-have, it's essential. Plus, when employees know they're supported in their wellness, they tend to perform way better. It's time companies walk the talk on wellness.

Headline: Co-Founder @ Career Pitstop | Driving Professional & Youth Transformation | Leadership | Career Mastery | Global Change Management
Comment:
Well said Dilip - Often, we blame external circumstances for our failure to maintain a healthy lifestyle (tight deadlines, demanding projects, constant hustle). But deep down, we all realize that, eventually, it is the pursuit of a sound body and mind that truly matters. You rightly pointed out "Becoming unhealthy is not an event, but a slow process - just like losing money, it is the culmination of neglect over time."

It is time for organizations to also catch up. Some visionary companies have already started investing in the well-being of their employees, redefining what it means to care for their teams, often called "family." This is more than a trend - it is a necessary evolution in the way we work and live.

In the end, health isn‚Äôt just a personal responsibility‚Äîit is a collective one. If we can foster an environment where well-being is prioritized at all levels, both individuals and businesses can thrive together.
